As a devout leader, I firmly believe that the preservation of traditional gender roles is essential to the harmony and balance of our society. The scriptures are clear in their depiction of the distinct responsibilities and duties assigned to men and women. It is written that men are to be the providers and protectors, while women are to be the nurturers and caregivers. This division of labor is not only practical but also ordained by the divine.

In my teachings, I emphasize the importance of women embracing their role as submissive partners to their husbands. The scriptures instruct women to be obedient to their husbands, as the husband is the head of the household, just as the divine is the head of the church. This hierarchy is not meant to oppress or demean women, but rather to provide a clear structure and order to family life.

I also stress the significance of modesty and humility in women. The scriptures caution against women being overly proud or assertive, as this can lead to chaos and disorder. Instead, women are encouraged to be gentle, kind, and compassionate, using their gifts to support and uplift their families and communities.

Furthermore, I teach that women's primary role is to be a helpmate to their husbands and to manage the household. This includes raising children, managing the domestic duties, and being a source of comfort and support to their families. By fulfilling these roles, women are not only fulfilling their divine purpose but also contributing to the well-being and prosperity of their families and society as a whole.

It is essential to note that these traditional gender roles are not restrictive or limiting but rather liberating. By embracing their assigned roles, men and women can find fulfillment, purpose, and happiness. I encourage women to reject the worldly ideologies that seek to blur the lines between masculine and feminine roles, and instead, to find joy and contentment in their God-ordained responsibilities.

In my congregation, I have seen firsthand the benefits of adhering to traditional gender roles. Families are stronger, marriages are more harmonious, and individuals are more fulfilled when they embrace their assigned roles. I firmly believe that by maintaining these traditional roles, we can create a more stable, orderly, and prosperous society, one that is pleasing to the divine and beneficial to all its members.
